Expectation1: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation1: A school zone with children near the curb appears just as a construction detour narrows the lanes
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They recognize the importance of being present at weekly services regularly
Story: I glanced at the dashboard clock—8:45 a.m. Sunday. My shift was almost over, and I was determined to make it to church on time. The route I usually took was blocked by construction, forcing me through a school zone. Children clustered near the curb, their backpacks bright against the gray morning. The detour sign blinked, and traffic crawled. I felt the pressure mounting; if I didn’t hurry, I’d miss the opening hymn and the sense of belonging I craved each week. But as a taxi driver, I knew the rules: slow down, be vigilant, protect the kids. My foot hovered over the brake, heart pounding. The urge to speed up tugged at me—church was waiting, my community expecting me. Yet, the responsibility to drive safely, to honor the trust of parents and the law, weighed just as heavily. I gripped the wheel, torn between my duty to my faith and my duty to the children outside.
